citation: The objective of the treaty is to end plastic pollution through a comprehensive approach that takes into account the life cycle of plastic from design to production, and the prevention and management of plastic pollution.

In its resolution 5/14 of 2 March 2022, entitled "Ending plastic pollution: towards an international legally binding instrument", the United Nations Environment Assembly sets out the general objective of the treaty.
Measures to minimize total pollution through improved waste management, sanitation activities and other measures to prevent, reduce, eliminate and control plastic pollution.

In doing so, Burkina Faso, in its drive to put an end to plastic pollution and its effects on health and the environment, adopted in 2014 the law banning the production, importation, marketing and distribution of non-biodegradable plastic packaging and bags.
end_plastic_pollution.reasoning: The document explicitly states multiple times that the objective of the treaty is to 'end plastic pollution'. This is mentioned as the primary objective, is supported by referencing the UN resolution title 'Ending plastic pollution', and is aligned with the country's own national 'drive to put an end to plastic pollution'. While the goal is clear, no specific target year or global timeframe for its achievement is mentioned in the text.

citation: The objective of the treaty is to end plastic pollution through a comprehensive approach that takes into account the life cycle of plastic from design to production, and the prevention and management of plastic pollution.

Measures to minimize total pollution through plastic pollution prevention: focus on banning and phasing out certain problematic plastics, in limiting their entry into the market and their release into the environment.

protect_human_health.details: The document lists protecting human health as a core objective of the treaty. It specifies that control measures, such as banning and phasing out problematic plastics (e.g., single-use plastics and those with chemical additives), will reduce their negative effects on human health. It also notes the need for further research on the long-term health effects of plastic pollution.

This will reduce their potential negative effects on human and animal health. This concerns single-use plastics and those containing chemical additives.

In doing so, Burkina Faso, in its drive to put an end to plastic pollution and its effects on health and the environment, adopted in 2014 the law banning the production, importation, marketing and distribution of non-biodegradable plastic packaging and bags.

It directly links control measures for problematic plastics to the reduction of 'potential negative effects on human and animal health'. Furthermore, it frames Burkina Faso's national legislation as a response to the 'effects on health and the environment' caused by plastic pollution, and identifies the long-term health effects as an area requiring more scientific research, solidifying its relevance.

citation: protect human and animal health;
preserve the quality of soil, water and air;

In its resolution 5/14 entitled “Ending plastic pollution: towards an international legally binding instrument”, the Environment Assembly noted that plastic pollution, in marine and other environments, can be transboundary in nature and should be addressed, along with its impacts, through a full life cycle approach, taking into account national circumstances and capabilities.

These are direct proxies for protecting wildlife and ecosystems. Furthermore, it specifically highlights the need to address plastic pollution in "marine and other environments," indicating a distinct focus that includes marine biodiversity.

citation: The objective of the treaty is to end plastic pollution through a comprehensive approach that takes into account the life cycle of plastic from design to production, and the prevention and management of plastic pollution.

...plastic pollution, in marine and other environments, can be transboundary in nature and should be addressed, along with its impacts, through a full life cycle approach, taking into account national circumstances and capabilities.

subsidies.details: The document calls for financial assistance and support for developing countries to implement the treaty. This includes funding for strategic interventions, pilot projects, and demonstration projects aimed at launching a circular economy.

waste_management.details: Improved waste management, sanitation activities, carrying out clean-up operations, control of plastic waste flows (applying Bamako and Basel conventions), recovery of plastic waste, and ecological management of plastic waste.
citation: Measures to minimize total pollution through improved waste management, sanitation activities and other measures to prevent, reduce, eliminate and control plastic pollution.
Measures to minimize total pollution through better control of waste flows plastics through the application of the Bamako and Basel conventions.
take measures to eliminate plastic pollution by controlling the use of plastic and carrying out clean-up operations;
Also, in January 2023, the country adopted a national plastic waste management strategy and action plan. These are essential planning tools for coordinating the fight against plastic pollution.
This national strategy is structured around three (03) axes: (i) Prevention of plastic pollution; (ii) Recovery of plastic waste; (iii) Governance of ecological management of plastic waste.
waste_management.reasoning: The document explicitly lists 'improved waste management' and 'sanitation activities' as fundamental control measures. It also cites Burkina Faso's national strategy, which includes specific responsibilities for the sector such as 'Recovery of plastic waste' and 'ecological management of plastic waste'. Furthermore, it mentions 'control of waste flows' and 'clean-up operations' as necessary actions, which directly involve the waste management sector's operational role.

informal_sector.details: The document references Burkina Faso's national plastic waste management strategy, which includes the vision to create 'decent green jobs' within the plastic waste sector.
citation: The vision of the strategy is that by 2027, "the plastic waste sector driven by modern initiatives, in line with a circularity perspective, is competitive, creating decent green jobs guaranteeing a healthy environment for the daughters and sons of Burkina Faso."
informal_sector.reasoning: While the document does not explicitly use terms like 'informal sector' or 'waste pickers', it refers to a national strategy for the 'plastic waste sector' that aims to create 'decent green jobs'. This implies a recognition of the workforce within this sector and an objective to formalize or improve their roles and socio-economic conditions, which is a clear reference to the responsibilities and future role of these workers.

government.details: National-level implementation of the treaty, including the development of national action plans and strategies, transposing international guidelines into national law, establishing regulatory frameworks, enacting specific laws (e.g., banning certain plastics), coordinating anti-pollution efforts, and institutional strengthening through the creation of regulatory agencies and management committees.
citation: National plans should be aligned with the regional strategy to enable States to transpose the guidelines on combating plastic pollution both preventively and curatively.
Beyond shared obligations, countries will need to put in place an additional regulatory framework for implementing the treaty.

In doing so, Burkina Faso, in its drive to put an end to plastic pollution and its effects on health and the environment, adopted in 2014 the law banning the production, importation, marketing and distribution of non-biodegradable plastic packaging and bags.

Institutional strengthening increases the capacity of governments to carry out their core functions and has become synonymous with support provided to ensure coherence and dedication through staffing within governments, for example, focal points, Management Committees or Regulatory Agencies for plastics management.
government.reasoning: The document consistently outlines the obligations of national governments (referred to as 'States' or 'countries') in combating plastic pollution. The citations confirm that governments are responsible for creating national plans, establishing regulatory frameworks, enacting legislation, and forming institutional bodies like regulatory agencies. The specific example of Burkina Faso's 2014 law further solidifies this role.

un_system.details: The document references the United Nations Environment Assembly setting the general objective for the treaty. It also advocates for a Conference of the Parties (COP) to adjust control measures over time and for the application of existing international conventions like the Bamako and Basel conventions.
citation: In its resolution 5/14 of 2 March 2022, entitled "Ending plastic pollution: towards an international legally binding instrument", the United Nations Environment Assembly sets out the general objective of the treaty.

The agreement should contain a start-up and strengthening mechanism to adjust control measures over time through decisions of the Conference of the Parties (COP), similar to what exists in the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants, and in the Montreal Protocol on the Management of Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer.
Measures to minimize total pollution through better control of waste flows plastics through the application of the Bamako and Basel conventions.
un_system.reasoning: The text explicitly names the 'United Nations Environment Assembly' and assigns it the role of setting the treaty's objective. It further proposes a 'Conference of the Parties (COP)', a standard international governance body for such treaties, to be responsible for adjusting control measures. The reference to applying the Bamako and Basel conventions also implies a role for their respective international secretariats and governing bodies.
